newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Hongkong Land aims more China projects.
newsitem.headline: Hongkong Land aims more China projects.

text.p: Hongkong Land Holdings said on Friday its projects in China were focused in Beijing, where it expected to get involved in a development project this year.
"In China, our efforts currently are focused in Beijing. We hope in 1997 to bring a development project in there forward," Hongkong Land managing director Percy Weatherall told reporters.
It hoped to finalise a deal on an office development in China this year, he added two days after the company announced 1996 net profits of US$649 million.
Hongkong Land was also eyeing more water treatment projects in China through its 33-percent owned China Water Co.

"We are involved in one project in Shenyang and are pursuing new opportunities within China on the water front. I strongly expect in 1997 we will get involved in several projects and we will be supporting this company with fresh equity," he said.

Weatherall said another city in China where the company was keen to do business was Shanghai, highly likely to develop into a financial centre and a good market for Hongkong Land as a high portion of its tenants were from the finance sector.
In Singapore, Hongkong Land expected its office and retail development, Esplanade Mall, to be ready in 2000. Development and the purchase of the site totalled US$430 million.
In Indonesia, the company has a stake of 20 percent in a second toll road project which runs east of Jakarta, connecting Cikampek to Padalarang.
Construction would start around April-May 1998 and the investment was expected to start paying dividends in 2003, Weatherall said.
Its US$30 million investment in the existing Indonesian Tangerang-Merak toll road was expected to start paying dividends in 2002, he said.

While Hongkong Land was expanding into transportation and water, it did not see these contributing more than 5-10 percent of the company's revenue and profit in the next five years, finance director Ian Durant said.
Weatherall said the company was looking at opportunites in power projects and "recognised telecommunications as an interesting area".
